values.description:
This pull request modifies the installer to use the latest tagged version of lyse in the default branch, which as of today is the Qt version (it has been merged into default and tagged as 2.0.0).

Also removes mise from the installer, which is still gtk based. Any future version of mise once the new optimisation spec is implemented will reappear once it's done. Anyone wanting to use mise in the meantime has a much more complicated install process on account of it using gtk, and that is outside the scope of this installer.
values.title: Qt lyse goes default, mise removed for now

summary.raw:
This pull request modifies the installer to use the latest tagged version of lyse in the default branch, which as of today is the Qt version (it has been merged into default and tagged as 2.0.0).

Also removes mise from the installer, which is still gtk based. Any future version of mise once the new optimisation spec is implemented will reappear once it's done. Anyone wanting to use mise in the meantime has a much more complicated install process on account of it using gtk, and that is outside the scope of this installer.
summary.html:
This pull request modifies the installer to use the latest tagged version of lyse in the default branch, which as of today is the Qt version (it has been merged into default and tagged as 2.0.0).

Also removes mise from the installer, which is still gtk based. Any future version of mise once the new optimisation spec is implemented will reappear once it's done. Anyone wanting to use mise in the meantime has a much more complicated install process on account of it using gtk, and that is outside the scope of this installer.

values.description:
On a whim I decided to setup a Python 3 labscript environment just to be ready and ran the installation from scratch, finding a few bugs.

setup.py is already set up to run under python 2 or 3, but needs to alias raw_input to input for python 3.

Discovered an obtuse path quirk for the icon cache clearing when running 32-bit python on 64-bit windows. See [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38154806/python-os-system-subprocess-do-not-recognize-microsofts-ie4uinit-exe) for details on why.

(not included in this pull request, obviously) labscript_utils.winshell __init__.py has a StringIO import that would need to be io.StringIO for python 3. However, the import isn't actually used and can be removed outright as far as I can tell.
values.title: Fixes for installer to run with Python 3

summary.raw:
On a whim I decided to setup a Python 3 labscript environment just to be ready and ran the installation from scratch, finding a few bugs.

setup.py is already set up to run under python 2 or 3, but needs to alias raw_input to input for python 3.

Discovered an obtuse path quirk for the icon cache clearing when running 32-bit python on 64-bit windows. See [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38154806/python-os-system-subprocess-do-not-recognize-microsofts-ie4uinit-exe) for details on why.

(not included in this pull request, obviously) labscript_utils.winshell __init__.py has a StringIO import that would need to be io.StringIO for python 3. However, the import isn't actually used and can be removed outright as far as I can tell.
summary.html:
On a whim I decided to setup a Python 3 labscript environment just to be ready and ran the installation from scratch, finding a few bugs.

setup.py is already set up to run under python 2 or 3, but needs to alias raw_input to input for python 3.

Discovered an obtuse path quirk for the icon cache clearing when running 32-bit python on 64-bit windows. See here for details on why.

(not included in this pull request, obviously) labscript_utils.winshell init.py has a StringIO import that would need to be io.StringIO for python 3. However, the import isn't actually used and can be removed outright as far as I can tell.

values.description:
* Changed shared drive in default config file to ~/labscript_shared on unix
 * removed mise port from default config file
 * Introduced app_saved_configs path in config file
 * change runmanager and lyse autoload_config_file settings to use app_saved_configs
 * made installer create default app_saved_configs folder in userlib.

* Close Py3_bugfix branch
values.title: Added app_saved_configs, remove mise, default shared drive change

summary.raw:
* Changed shared drive in default config file to ~/labscript_shared on unix
 * removed mise port from default config file
 * Introduced app_saved_configs path in config file
 * change runmanager and lyse autoload_config_file settings to use app_saved_configs
 * made installer create default app_saved_configs folder in userlib.

* Close Py3_bugfix branch
summary.html:
• Changed shared drive in default config file to ~/labscript_shared on unix
  • removed mise port from default config file
  • Introduced app_saved_configs path in config file
  • change runmanager and lyse autoload_config_file settings to use app_saved_configs

  • made installer create default app_saved_configs folder in userlib.

  • Close Py3_bugfix branch

values.description:
As of recent Anacondas (not sure when exactly), one gets errors about loading DLLS when launching labscript suite apps from shortcuts. We've gotten a few emails about this, but I had assumed they were all misconfigured installations and not our fault (since that is easy to do with pip and conda battling each other, and for many other lamentable reasons). Well, it turns out it's our problem after all. Newish conda needs you to activate the environment first. I checked out how spyder does it, and modified the installer to do that if it detects its being run from conda.

Also add quotes to the strings in the shortcuts to escape potential spaces in filepaths.

I have yet to test that this doesn't break on Python 2, and anaconda 2 does not seem to have the DLL loading issue in any case. But it should still be the same conda with the same environment variables, so I imagine it should still work. But will test soon (it just takes ages to install anaconda on Windows)
values.title: Make shortcuts compatible with conda

Well, it turns out it's our problem after all. Newish conda needs you to activate the environment first. I checked out how spyder does it, and modified the installer to do that if it detects its being run from conda.

I have yet to test that this doesn't break on Python 2, and anaconda 2 does not seem to have the DLL loading issue in any case. But it should still be the same conda with the same environment variables, so I imagine it should still work. But will test soon (it just takes ages to install anaconda on Windows)

As of recent Anacondas (not sure when exactly), one gets errors about loading DLLS when launching labscript suite apps from shortcuts. We've gotten a few emails about this, but I had assumed they were all misconfigured installations and not our fault (since that is easy to do with pip and conda battling each other, and for many other lamentable reasons). Well, it turns out it's our problem after all. Newish conda needs you to activate the environment first. I checked out how spyder does it, and modified the installer to do that if it detects its being run from conda.

Also add quotes to the strings in the shortcuts to escape potential spaces in filepaths.

I have yet to test that this doesn't break on Python 2, and anaconda 2 does not seem to have the DLL loading issue in any case. But it should still be the same conda with the same environment variables, so I imagine it should still work. But will test soon (it just takes ages to install anaconda on Windows)

values.description:
Set default output_folder_format and filename_prefix_format to use new integer
sequence_index introduced in runmanager.

This should not be merged until the corresponding runmanager changes are merged and stamped
with a version number, since otherwise fresh installs will have a runmanager that does not format
the output_folder_format properly.
values.title: Use sequence_index in default output folder and filename prefix

summary.raw:
Set default output_folder_format and filename_prefix_format to use new integer
sequence_index introduced in runmanager.

This should not be merged until the corresponding runmanager changes are merged and stamped
with a version number, since otherwise fresh installs will have a runmanager that does not format
the output_folder_format properly.
summary.html:
Set default output_folder_format and filename_prefix_format to use new integer sequence_index introduced in runmanager.

This should not be merged until the corresponding runmanager changes are merged and stamped with a version number, since otherwise fresh installs will have a runmanager that does not format the output_folder_format properly.

values.description:
Latest anaconda breaks our installer by removing the CONDA_PYTHON_EXE environment variable.

This PR modifies our installer to use CONDA_EXE instead. This variable exists in previous anacondas too, so is backward compatible back to at least version 4.4, which the installer checks the currently running version is at least as high as.

Rejig the version check to call conda and ask for the version rather than assuming it based on environment variables.

We previously used CONDA_PYTHON_EXE to determine the location of pythonw.exe
and cwp.py. But it was removed in conda 4.6.11. Now we find pythonw.exe and
cwp.py as relative paths to CONDA_EXE, which points to a known path in
the root environment.

Assumptions are made in either case about where things are located within the
anaconda directory, but this cannot be helped since there is no way to know
where these scripts and executables are in any canonical way at the moment.
values.title: In conda 4.6.11, CONDA_PYTHON_EXE does not exist. Modify to use CONDA_EXE instead.

summary.raw:
Latest anaconda breaks our installer by removing the CONDA_PYTHON_EXE environment variable.

This PR modifies our installer to use CONDA_EXE instead. This variable exists in previous anacondas too, so is backward compatible back to at least version 4.4, which the installer checks the currently running version is at least as high as.

Rejig the version check to call conda and ask for the version rather than assuming it based on environment variables.

We previously used CONDA_PYTHON_EXE to determine the location of pythonw.exe
and cwp.py. But it was removed in conda 4.6.11. Now we find pythonw.exe and
cwp.py as relative paths to CONDA_EXE, which points to a known path in
the root environment.

Assumptions are made in either case about where things are located within the
anaconda directory, but this cannot be helped since there is no way to know
where these scripts and executables are in any canonical way at the moment.
summary.html:
Latest anaconda breaks our installer by removing the CONDA_PYTHON_EXE environment variable.

This PR modifies our installer to use CONDA_EXE instead. This variable exists in previous anacondas too, so is backward compatible back to at least version 4.4, which the installer checks the currently running version is at least as high as.

Rejig the version check to call conda and ask for the version rather than assuming it based on environment variables.

We previously used CONDA_PYTHON_EXE to determine the location of pythonw.exe and cwp.py. But it was removed in conda 4.6.11. Now we find pythonw.exe and cwp.py as relative paths to CONDA_EXE, which points to a known path in the root environment.

Assumptions are made in either case about where things are located within the anaconda directory, but this cannot be helped since there is no way to know where these scripts and executables are in any canonical way at the moment.

values.description:
Added detailed installation and setup instructions.
Edited the error message about updating conda to only update the base conda
Put connection table template `start()` and `stop()` calls in a `if __name__ == '__main__'` block.
values.title: Much more detailed installation and setup instructions.

summary.raw:
Added detailed installation and setup instructions.
Edited the error message about updating conda to only update the base conda
Put connection table template `start()` and `stop()` calls in a `if __name__ == '__main__'` block.
summary.html: Added detailed installation and setup instructions. Edited the error message about updating conda to only update the base conda Put connection table template start() and stop() calls in a if __name__ == '__main__' block.

values.description:
Remove suggestion to install packages via 'web'. Pip can now handle binary packages just fine, is the standard method of distribution, and comes with Python, so there is no need for web installers anymore.

Add configparser dependency - this is the backported 'configparser' module from
Python 3.5 for Python 2. On Python 3 this check succeeds due to the stdlib module,
so no need to make the check version-specific.
Align output of installer when checking depdencies. Makes it easier to read.

Configparser dependency is for [labscript_utils pull request 76](#!/labscript_suite/labscript_utils/pull-requests/76/)
values.title: configparser dependency, and dependency cleanups.

summary.raw:

Add configparser dependency - this is the backported 'configparser' module from
Python 3.5 for Python 2. On Python 3 this check succeeds due to the stdlib module,
so no need to make the check version-specific.
Align output of installer when checking depdencies. Makes it easier to read.

Configparser dependency is for [labscript_utils pull request 76](#!/labscript_suite/labscript_utils/pull-requests/76/)
summary.html:
Remove suggestion to install packages via 'web'. Pip can now handle binary packages just fine, is the standard method of distribution, and comes with Python, so there is no need for web installers anymore.

Add configparser dependency - this is the backported 'configparser' module from Python 3.5 for Python 2. On Python 3 this check succeeds due to the stdlib module, so no need to make the check version-specific. Align output of installer when checking depdencies. Makes it easier to read.

Configparser dependency is for labscript_utils pull request 76

values.description:
Include list of BLACS plugins in default config file. Reorder sections so that programs are together and in order. Move paths section closer to the top.
Use $HOME environment variable in default labscript shared folder on unix.
values.title: Config file reordering and more default options included.

values.description:
This PR moves a number of functions from setup.py into labscript_utils.winshell in order to make them available for appid stuff at run time. Once the labscript_utils PR is merged and stamped with a version number, this can be merged.

This along with the labscript_utils PR, solves issue #28

See the [labscript_utils PR](#!/labscript_suite/labscript_utils/pull-requests/update/79) for rationale.
values.title: Move functions into winshell

See the [labscript_utils PR](#!/labscript_suite/labscript_utils/pull-requests/update/79) for rationale.

See the labscript_utils PR for rationale.

values.description:
It is used by [labscript PR 48](#!/labscript_suite/labscript/pull-requests/48/marker-colour-enhancements) to convert marker colour names to RGB values, and by a the [LightCrafter DMD PR](#!/labscript_suite/labscript_devices/pull-requests/43), to produce BMP images from numpy arrays.

It will already be present on most anaconda installs.

I will merge on Monday if there are no comments.
values.title: Add pillow as dependency

summary.raw:
It is used by [labscript PR 48](#!/labscript_suite/labscript/pull-requests/48/marker-colour-enhancements) to convert marker colour names to RGB values, and by a the [LightCrafter DMD PR](#!/labscript_suite/labscript_devices/pull-requests/43), to produce BMP images from numpy arrays.

It will already be present on most anaconda installs.

I will merge on Monday if there are no comments.

values.description:
Add `_{script_basename}` to default `filename_prefix_format`. It was intended
to be there in the recent sequence index changes, but I mistakenly left it out.
Without it, shots from different scripts aren't so easily identifiable in lyse,
even though the filepath contains the script name in the folder hierarchy
values.title: re-add script basename to default shot filename

summary.raw:
Add `_{script_basename}` to default `filename_prefix_format`. It was intended
to be there in the recent sequence index changes, but I mistakenly left it out.
Without it, shots from different scripts aren't so easily identifiable in lyse,
even though the filepath contains the script name in the folder hierarchy
summary.html: Add _{script_basename} to default filename_prefix_format. It was intended to be there in the recent sequence index changes, but I mistakenly left it out. Without it, shots from different scripts aren't so easily identifiable in lyse, even though the filepath contains the script name in the folder hierarchy
